awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Programming mesostructured colloidal soft matter through complex quenching and annealing
awd_abstract_narration:
The project supports integrated experiments, modeling and simulations to enable new ways of controlling material properties through thermal processing of colloidal materials. The goal is to develop new colloidal suspensions with temperature-sensitive interactions, and strategies by which they can be controllably processed into colloidal solids with desired structure and mechanical properties through quenching, annealing and tempering. The development of these new tools and the knowledge they create could lead to transformative new and scalable processing methods for colloidal materials with well-controlled and novel properties, and potentially impact a range of technologies including artificial tissue scaffolds, separation membranes, and inks for additive manufacturing. The research will be integrated with educational activities to train students in a new approach to making colloidal solids having unique structures and properties.

Thermal processing has long been known and employed for atomic and molecular materials, but has been elusive in colloidal materials because of a lack of colloidal systems with easily controlled temperature-responsive behavior, as well as a dearth of fundamental understanding for how the thermal history influences the development and arrest of structural morphologies and features in these systems. In this project, these challenges will be overcome using newly developed thermoresponsive colloids, and large-scale simulations and experiments that can rapidly probe the multitude of possible thermal histories and structures that emerge from them. Experiments and simulation will be combined to characterize how kinetic trajectories in thermodynamic variables map onto the relevant descriptors of emergent structural correlations and material properties including rheology. Leading efforts will establish categorical behavior for quenches in the homogeneous fluid phase, as well as in both metastable (binodal) and unstable (spinodal) regions of phase coexistence, followed on by more complex quenches involving annealing in more than one of these regions to seek out novel structures and rheology. Doing so will enable a more fundamental understanding for how kinetic processes of gelation, phase separation and glass formation compete in colloidal fluids to initiate, evolve and eventually arrest structure, and how the features of the arrested structure control the linear and non-linear mechanics of the material. This fundamental understanding will be used to develop a new conceptual framework for using thermal processing to design and engineer colloidal materials with well-specified structure and properties.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the University of California

por.por_cntn:
Repeated heating and cooling of metals and other hard materials has been used for millenia to transform raw materials into materials with exceptional strength, ductility, or even aesthetic properties, with perhaps the most recognizable being Damascus steel. Only recently has scientific analysis revealed the underlying atomic and molecular processes that take place during these quench-and-anneal processes -- rearrangements that transform the microscopic structure within the material, leading to superior properties. These advances have ushered in an entirely new era in the development of ceramic, polymeric, and other materials leading to development of artificial joints, heart stents, heat shields for rockets, Teflon coatings for cooking, bullet-proof vests, and many more. The underlying principle driving these powerful process-structure-property relationships is that the rates associated with competing processes of molecular motion and phase transformation change as the temperature changes, and this sets the balance between various physical processes that compete to rearrange material structure. In this way, heat can be used to rearrange materials into stronger or more optically useful structures, for example, and then cold can be used to lock them into place. Repeated temperature cycling can reinforce these rearrangements into patterns over many length scales and thus produce more and greater functionality. Meanwhile, an entirely new class of particulate-based materials emerged in the 20th century, involving microscopic particles embedded in a background fluid which can exhibit solid-like behavior under weak imposed forces but can liquify when stressed then re-solidify when stress is removed. The underlying properties responsible for this unusual behavior - found when we spread butter, smooth hair gel, expel mucus, or eat our favorite dairy products - emerge from the interactions between particles and the associated structures they make in a way that is far from currently understood. The primary aim of this project was to bring the knowledge of quench-anneal strategies used to sculpt molecular materials to these newer particulate-based soft materials. Such techniques did not exist previously for particulate matter because (a) model material and computational model systems did not exist, and (b) the time scales of rearrangement for the suspended particles are vastly different than those of the suspending fluid, deeply complicating the structure-property evolution during quench-and-anneal cycles, especially when the material becomes thermodynamically "stuck" or arrested in a non-equilibrium state that cannot be described by existing theories.

Our research accomplished this central scientific objective by developing new understanding for how non-equilibrium, arrested states in soft matter dynamically evolve during such complex temperature histories. To do so, we developed a tandem set of experiments and large-scale computer simulations for a model material system whose composition is not unlike dairy products --- tiny non-deformable droplets suspended in a liquid, where molecular linkers reversibly bond the droplets together when temperature changes, creating liquid, gel, and glassy material states. We discovered that the temperature-sensitive solidification of these materials depends on an interplay of percolation (the formation of an extended network of particle "bonds"), phase separation (the tendency to form regions of low and high particle concentration), and glassy arrest (where crowding of particles prevents structural rearrangement). Critically, we demonstrated that the interplay of these three processes can be widely tuned through the temperature history subjected to the material when transforming from the liquid to the solid state, providing a time window of processability in which thermal processing can dramatically alter the structure and properties of the material as it forms. Unexpectedly, we found that this window occurs after the initial solidification process, and that structural rearrangement proceeds by delayed phase separation on the way to glassy arrest. Using detailed mechanical and structural measurements, we identified the microscopic mechanisms by which this sequence occurs, and proposed a simple theory that explains how the rate of structural rearrangement changes with temperature. Leveraging this new understanding for thermal processing of soft solids, we created broader impact on science: we developed quench-anneal-quench processes that can be used to tune the sizes of intermediate structures in the final material, and as a result dramatically alter its mechanical properties. These results provide new design principles for tailoring the processing, structure and properties of soft solids using thermal processing, and could impact a number of technologies spanning additive manufacturing, foods and consumer products, and biopharmaceuticals. Our work also created broader impacts in terms of leading to the PhDs of several graduate students; educating colleagues in academia and industry via short courses; diversity, equity and inclusion in our research groups and in reaching undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 04/03/2023
Modified by: Matthew E Helgeson
